column4: Post

I thought I would start with something easy- define cultural inclusivity.  This seems like a concept I should innately know, but I still struggle to define it.

Cultural inclusivity:  being mutually respectful, recognizing my own biases, avoiding assumptions based on specific characteristics such as race/ location/ language/ gender, possessing flexibility to accommodate all persons and ideas

Hi Dixie, 

I really like your definition of cultural inclusivity. I would build off of that and add that by starting with mindset that you described, cultural inclusivity is further practiced by valuing ideas that are different than our own. Like you mentioned, we are respectful, and recognize our biases, and through that mindset we take the time to consider ideas that are different. I think it's a step beyond tolerant, to actually find value in what others bring to the table, even if we do not ultimately agree.

Hi Dixie and Stephanie,

Thanks for starting off the discussion! I am tied into my work schedule and will probably not be able to step in during the day over the next week as we move forward.

I am wondering whether we can follow the string of questions that Lani provided and see whether we can approach them as different aspects of one topic and/or if there is a causality that needs to be addressed as move forward to get to a deeper understanding of what cultural diversity is relative to eLearning in the WisCom framework.

I think Justin's summary of our answers will help move along the discussion, so please let us wait for feedback and be sure to check in with where Justin is at in synthesizing what we bring to the table.

Dixie's initial definition with Stephanie's qualification and addition are a great starting point, so I invite everyone to build on Dixie and Stephanie's suggestions - and I assume, we can reference Justin's posts as we build a wider definition, which can move us forward to looking at the theories of learning that support cultural inclusivity.

Thanks again! Eva

Hi Everyone, 

Here's my interpretation, I apologize about the length, but I wanted to focus on how we can create a culturally inclusive eLearning experience using the WisCom framework. 

My definition of cultural inclusivity is the act of incorporating cultures into something. In terms of eLearning, this means that an instructor should get to know their students and learn more about their cultures. This allows the instructor to create content that is relevant to everyone and does not contain language barriers and free of stereotypes. As discussed in chapter 1, instructional designers should think about the three levels of adapting a course which are translation, localization, and modularization (Marinetti & Dunn, 2012). This process meets the requirements of creating a culturally inclusive eLearning experience because it is removing cultural barriers that prevent learners from interacting with the content.

Instructional designers can create a culturally inclusive classroom by using the ingredients of the WisCom framework: 

Communication: Through communication, learners can pass on their cultural knowledge to others as opposed to allowing one dominant group to be held responsible for passing on knowledge such as the instructor. It also allows people to understand each other better and help the instructor understand what is needed for learners to be successful and valued within the eLearning community. 
Community: Cultural inclusivity allows for communities to develop where people in an online environment can come together and build a tight-knit group. I noticed how comfortable we are interacting with each other on the discussion boards that when we met for our second Zoom meeting, some of us were interacting like we've known each other for a long time! That is one of the wonderful things about building a community that is culturally inclusive where people respect each other's views and choices.
Technology: We need to be cognizant that not everyone knows how to use a computer, or does not have the bandwidth to do certain things so we need to be patient, teach others, and provide different resources so everyone can meet learning objectives. A culturally inclusive eLearning course does not solely rely on technology; they provide other mediums such as books, handouts, and other resources.
Co-mentoring: We need to work with people of different backgrounds which was something recommended by Tao & Cornell (2003). Co-mentoring is also a great way to provide scaffolding which might be needed for some learners to be successful, and learn from each other.
Problem- solving and collaborative inquiry cycle: It is important to remember that not everyone has the same thought process and some cultures focus more on collaborative thinking than individual thinking (Bentley, Tinney, & Chia, 2005). Culturally inclusive classrooms are a mix of individual and collaborative thinking just like we are doing right now. We are sharing our views and synthesizing them into a summary at the end. 
Wisdom: A "wise" instructional designer intentionally creates a culturally inclusive eLearning experience by putting their own culture aside and looking for ways to build a strong learning community
Transformational learning: transformational learning takes place when learning environments allow learners to change their ways of thinking by interacting with learners of a different culture. This is the only way that transformational learning takes place, in my opinion, because sticking to our own beliefs or cultural group will not produce genuine transformational learning because we are not giving up anything. 
Learner support: Cultural inclusivity is all about providing support for the learner. A true culturally inclusive eLearning experience has different support systems for every learner to be successful.

Resources

Bentley, J.P.H., Tinney, M.V., & Chia, B.H. (2005). Intercultural internet-based learning: Know your audience and what it values. Educational Technology Research & Development, 53(2), 117-127.

Gunawardena, C. N., Frechette, C., & Layne, L. (2018). Culturally Inclusive Instructional Design?: A Framework and Guide to Building Online Wisdom Communities. Routledge.

Marinetti, A., & Dunn, P. (2002). Cultural adaptation: Necessity for global e-learning. Retrieved August 15, 2017, from www.linezine.com/7.2/articles/pdamca.htm

Pan, C. -C., Tsai, M. -H., Tsai, P. -Y., Tao, Y., & Cornell, R. (2003). Technology's impact: Symbiotic or asymbiotic impact on differing cultures? Educational Media International, 40(3/4), 319-330.

Melissa,

As always, thank you for thoroughly and insightfully pushing forward the discussion and expanding what cultural inclusivity  in the context of our readings can look like. I invite others to elaborate on the principles of " translation, localization, and modularization " Melissa brings up and discuss the WisCom framework - perhaps you can relay instances in which one or the other WisCom framework touch points presented a challenge or you encountered a positive solution. There were already some interesting points brought up in our introductory culture/eLearning discussion that would illustrate some of these.

Thank you! Eva

Hmm, your mention of "incorporating cultures into something" gives me pause for thought. I really approached the definition of cultural inclusivity as one that specifically doesn't exclude someone's culture, but your definition definitely takes a proactive approach!
You bring up an excellent point, cultural inclusivity does not exclude someone's culture. I feel your definition aligns better with my vision.
I spent a lot of time thinking about this too! I sifted through many definitions to come to my own interpretation. It does seem like a term that we understand inherently but struggle to articulate!

It sure can be!  Its a little like "fair" or "unbiased".  I have a hard time putting it into words, but I think I know it when I see it.  
But, those things can mean very different things to different people.  Maybe it is the same with this?

Hi Dixie, Like culture, I find that defining cultural inclusivity is challenging. How would you apply your definition of cultural inclusivity to an environment where we don't know learners' location, preferred learning language, and ethnic identity?

Hey Mark, The key to building an inclusive classroom, whether traditional or eLearning, is by getting to know your students. It's important to think about what we are doing in this class. We spent the first week getting to know each other and we have the virtual cafe to share. Our responses are observed by our instructors and I've noticed that they are always acknowledging our responses during our sessions, which in my opinion, acknowledges that are making informal observations. That is why I believe eLearning courses need to rely on building a community in order for everyone to feel comfortable and feel motivated to learn.

I agree Melissa, And I also feel that by allowing there discussions to progress on their own without having such a narrow scope and strict or defined expectations allows for individuals to show their differences and add to the culture of the group in a way that is meaningful to themselves, while also learning what is meaningful to others.
Absolutely, I am glad that you agree! :)

Hello, Melissa.  I am glad you bring this up.  When I was taking HRDV classes for my undergrad, we were given a discussion prompt at some point about the possibility of removing bias during the hiring process by using only resumes and no interviews.  The resumes would be blinded of names and any other personal information that would give an indication of a person's gender, age, race, ethnicity, national origin, etc.  As I was reading the first chapter, I wondered if it would be a possibility for eLearning as well.  However, I agree with you on getting to know each other last week was quite pleasant, and I can already see that I am going to learn a lot from our folks here.  I think this is also the first online course I have taken where the instructors have been so engaged, so I am very excited to be part of community building as a student and am interested in where this takes us.

Hi Michelle! I am familiarized with this hiring process and I wonder if that would be helpful in an eLearning environment? I feel like sometimes we make assumptions about people based on the tiny images in our Blackboard course or the minimal conversations we have in discussion boards that it may be good to exclude some of this? I strongly feel though that communication and building a community will help create a better eLearning experience.

Getting to know one another and our professors is beneficial simply from a social/psychological perspective: I agree that eLearning (and really every course) should focus on building community.

I wonder (just for the sake of discussion) if it will ever be possible to design a culturally inclusive course simply because that is how we (humans) now teach? There has been so much social unrest this crazy year, but it has definitely opened society's collective eyes to culture and its most extreme forms of exclusion. Maybe someday humanity will reach a place where being sensitive and inclusive to other cultures is simply how things are done (I know, I know, a sci-fi utopian vision).

I agree. I wouldn't have been successful as a teacher if I didn't spend the first few weeks (6 weeks, times 5) getting to know my students and creating opportunities for them to belong to the classroom community. Of course, this is an investment that a lot of teachers don't have the time to commit to. In an online course time is a valuable commodity. How would you design a course that is inclusive?

Melissa, Lisa, Michelle M., Michelle C., Mark,

In agreement about how important communication is and hoping that the foment one sees around breaking open ground to speak leads to action - but even as I read and respond, there is another side to everything that is happening that indicates agreement on a set of rules and cooperation among participants is critical. So, in this community space how does one set boundaries that lead to genuine exchange without overstepping one or the other participant's cultural boundaries? I feel as if this process is one of squaring the circle trying to come to a concrete solution. In that context I appreciate how Authentic Learning and the use of real world, messy projects is the best way to get to work and try - nd in that process transformative learning would happen.

That is a very real challenge and one I have encountered.  I have been thinking more and more about some boundaries that are built into training I have constructed or reviewed.  Some of them were necessary, but some of them probably were not.  And some of those courses probably needed more boundaries.
Do you think it is possible to reduce boundaries to the point where students feel abandon?  How do you find the balance between the necessary framework and constructing a framework that is actually counter-productive?

Great point, Pete - I actually gave up on an online sports nutrition program because of lack of guidance, a book that was not user friendly, and the complete lack of interaction and guidance. Isn't the scope also dependent on participants? Perhaps there needs to be a flexible model which offers more or less boundaries in specific areas relative to how individuals would like to interact in the class. It would be interesting to run tests on how platforms change depending on the parameters participants choose and then see how these play out in real time. I don't know much about games but from the little bits I've seen, could this be similar to what one chooses to go on quests and what avatar one chooses etc? 

That brings up the issue of authenticity in a WisCom framework - there is an assumption one is participating with full integrity and authenticity, however, what happens when not everyone conforms to that ideal, which I would think is a given? So, sorry to just throw back a question at you. Eva

No, not at all!  Thats a cool analogy:  Quests and avatars. I'm not much of a gamer anymore and I know almost nothing about how to design one, but it is an interesting thought.  Especially in light of what you spoke about right before that.  I have had the same experience with certain apps that you had with the nutrition program.  And that made me think, "What was the root problem?"  I'd have to say that "Lack of adaptability" would probably be the most common source of frustration:  I can't make this thing fit with me and who I am and want to be.  Is an online learning environment essentially just an app?
And, I feel that authenticity and integrity are definitely a legitimate concerns.  I think you are right that we tend to assume that everyone is "all in" on both those.  But, that can be a dangerous assumption in some cases.  I'm not even sure it is conscious in many cases. I've been in learning environments with saboteurs "me firsters"d But, I know in many cases I have seen, there is a reluctance to be honest for fear of being labeled or marginalized because of that honesty.  Examples that I can think of might include the following:
"I'm taking this training because my boss ordered me to take it.  I'd rather be back at my "real" job.
"I'm only taking this class because it is required for my major."
"I think I might be in over my head in this class/training."
"We aren't even past the introductions and I already feel lost."
"I think I might be in the wrong room.  Everyone here seems way different/advanced/smarter/etc than me.  I don't feel like I belong here."

Now, I have actually heard that kind of stuff from students.  But, I think that kind of honesty is kind of rare.  That kind of honesty is hard to get out of people for legitimate reasons.  My experience is that it can be toxic to a learning environment if it isn't addressed.  I'll be honest and say I have no tried and true method of addressing it.  I probably failed, even when I recognized it.

This is so helpful - that root question - adaptability...makes me think of the low and high context cultural diversity piece and the opportunity eLearning might provide to actually escape it all - I just finished reading Isabel Wilkerson's Caste - and if it were possible in the context of a cyberculture/idioculture to shed the stereotypes of caste and focus on who one wants to present oneself as with one's unique culture, this could be an opportunity. Even to the point of those comments participants have made who don't really want to be in that environment - perhaps with the right "quest" settings in place a program could be modified to at some point get the participant interested.

Motivational Interviewing was developed by a psychologist here at UNM who created CASAA (the alcoholism and addition research center) - it's something I've been interested in with regard to motivation in learning for a while but now in the program I hope to learn more about it and see where that fits in. MI has become the most successful global therapy for alcoholism because it comes from the patient's point of entry/volition and not from an outside entity pushing something.

Without going too much into detail, I think it's important to consider what we are sharing in the discussion and utilizing the WisCom framework to guide us in creating an inclusive eLearning course. For example, not just relying on technology but offering other resources is a great way to be inclusive or utilizing simple language in our courses to make it easy for learners to follow along.

Hi Dixie! Thank you for starting this off. I would agree that the definition or answer is simple but it is hard to desrcibe. I struggled with trying to find a good way to summarize "cultural inclusivity". I think respect is something that is really important to keep in mind for this. We all come from different backgrounds but respecting each other for those difference as we form our own class culture is important.

Hi Amanda,

I agree with you.  I would say respect is extremely important, as well as understanding. I always explain to my students that we all come from different backgrounds and we all have different experiences and therefore we need to be understanding and respectful of each other.

Thank you for starting this conversation, cultural inclusivity is something I feel that I understand and is part of my everyday living and professional approach. However, I too struggle at times to encapsulate and articulate it in a way that supports those I teach and coach. In an early childhood classroom setting I describe this to teachers as recognizing and acknowledging difference, then embracing it as an opportunity and not a challenge. I try to have them think of it in terms of what can we do to include instead of focusing on what can’t be done or the barriers to doing what we know and what is comfortable. I strongly believe we have to look introspectively at our biases and be able to understand and acknowledge what is within ourselves in order to learn and grow with as well as from others. Interestingly, I have found that speaking in terms of accommodations tends to bring an interesting dynamic to the conversation, I am not sure if it elicits feelings of resistance due to bias or unfamiliarity but it feels like it creates a barrier. Has anyone else has experienced this? I tend to use words like incorporate, expand, adjust, encompass......

Regarding the dynamic you mentioned, do you mean that when you encourage people to be culturally inclusive they show resistance and so you use the other words you mentioned? That is very interesting. I wonder if it's indicative of the level of defensiveness many people in our country seem to express anytime the status quo is questioned or challenged. For me, cultural inclusivity seems like it should be our country's motto given that we have (until recently at least) claimed to welcome the world. But the last couple of years has taught me that there are many vocal opponents to this notion.

At any rate, you display effective communication by using words that get people to accomplish what you need them to do!

I don't believe it's the inclusivity that is the issue, I feel like it is something connected to the word accommodate...sort of like when you say conflict people automatically think it is a negative when in reality conflict is good and necessary and very much about perception and how that word has been internalized. I haven't done any probing to try and get at the heart of the reaction but I do find it interesting. I am most definitely a word choice person!!

Hi Dixie,

I like how you defined cultural inclusivity. When I think of the term cultural inclusivity, I think of all cultures being accepted. I really like how you included the being mutually respectful and possessing flexibility to accommodate all persons and ideas. I think this is very important because in order for inclusion to happen people need to be understanding and accepting, as well as respectful of each and everyone's race, language, beliefs, gender, etc.

Hello, Dixie. Your points about mutual respect and possessing flexibility to accommodate all people and ideas are paramount.  I have met people who feel threatened by the concept of cultural inclusivity, thinking it is a takeover of their own beliefs/set of values.   However, you seem to have summed it up rather effortlessly.  With mutual respect, individuals or groups from different cultures do not necessarily have to agree with or "convert" to the other's points of view, but they can acknowledge that both sides have the right to their own world views and each side has merit.  It also helps to have a set of rules as debated in the previous module's discussion to help ensure that respect is maintained.  I think this goes hand-in-hand with flexible accommodation - another topic that sometimes seems to threaten people.  Much of this probably stems from the other two points you included - people not recognizing their own biases and making assumptions.

Michelle,

I really like how you point out that when there is mutual respect, then everyone is able to acknowledge that both sides have a right to their own world views and each side has merit. This made me think of all of the political battles that are currently going on in our country.

We can define cultural inclusivity as a guarantee that all cultures participating in a given program/organization/society can access, participate, and express themselves in an equally valued manner.

The Collaborative Learning theory supports this goal because mutual participation is at the core of inclusivity.

Though we talk a great deal about the communication side of online course design, what struck me first when considering this question is the very notion that we are talking about a culturally exclusive group of people who even have access to an online environment. Within that framework, the degree of technological access and comfort with platforms varies greatly from person to person.

For example, in Albuquerque, APS has issued Chromebooks to all students this year to guarantee access to the technology since the end of the last term was marked by students not being able to access classes because they did not have a home computer. From my own experience, I find great fulfillment and value in Zoom classes and discussions, but am completely bamboozled by platforms like this one (Learn), which leaves me feeling like I am constantly missing something and can't find what I'm looking for! So cultural inclusivity should include these factors.

A culturally inclusive course design would then encompass the following:

1) A tangible platform that is accessible to all

2) Opportunities for participation are varied and integral to design

3) Discussions and problem solving assignments are not developed or graded for a "one correct answer" response

Hi Michelle, 

You brought up a point that really struck me. While APS may pass out Chromebooks to everyone therefore supposedly making remote learning accessible to everyone, there are still major gaps in that exist making the eLearning process not at all equitable. Some students (and their parents) do not have nearly as much experience with computers and/or the programs that are being used, which puts them at a disadvantage.

For instance, my middle school daughter and I have been struggling with turning things in on Google Classrooms. Sometimes the teachers tell her that what she turned in was blank even though we thought she did it right. I have no experience with this program that is completely different from Blackboard Learn, which I am very familiar with. Is it fair then for my daughter to get zeros for this issue? How could teachers handle these issue then to be more inclusive?

I liked Michelle's 3 components for an inclusive course design.  And can also relate to both Michelle and Stephanie's frustration with interacting with various different platforms.  This probably relates back to component #1- making a platform that is truly accessible to all.  It also ties in Mark's question- "how can we create inclusivity when we don't know someone's culture, language, or location?"

Some of the creators of software have recognized this need for universal understanding  and have created their own "culture neutral" language using pictures and symbols.  For example, a person of any language probably knows how to work a iphone.  Preschool children can work an iphone!  I think it is more complex to try to create a learning program/ course design using symbols and pictures, but the core concept is the same.

I liked Michelle's 3 components for an inclusive course design.  And can also relate to both Michelle and Stephanie's frustration with interacting with various different platforms.  This probably relates back to component #1- making a platform that is truly accessible to all.  It also ties in Mark's question- "how can we create inclusivity when we don't know someone's culture, language, or location?"

Some of the creators of software have recognized this need for universal understanding  and have created their own "culture neutral" language using pictures and symbols.  For example, a person of any language probably knows how to work a iphone.  Preschool children can work an iphone!  I think it is more complex to try to create a learning program/ course design using symbols and pictures, but the core concept is the same.

Not to sound too cynical, but I wonder if iPhone's design was spurred not so much by a desire to be culturally inclusive or more of a desire to be marketable to diverse cultures. Of course it was the latter, but Dixie's and your points are still completely valid and I agree with them absolutely! So I guess the big question is, how do we get designers on board with these concepts simply because its a good thing to do and not because there's a profit factor involved?

Michelle,
I'm not sure the two are mutually exclusive.  For example, my job is to help design training for a government agency.  If my training has inherent cultural bias, its likely to have a high failure rate.  A high failure rate is BAD:  That does not reflect well on me or the company for which I work.  We could lose the contract!
Is it possible that changing economic incentives could be the most effective way to change behaviors?
Apple may have changed their design because they saw a profit motive, but they did still change it.  And is it possible that this experience lead to an understanding in that company that they needed to be more culturally inclusive to survive?

Oh I share your frustration with a blank form! There definitely needs to be some understanding in the instructor's side of all eLearning about the technical side of teaching. I know many of these platforms and curricula were developed rapidly this year, so I think a healthy dose of flexibility is in order while the platforms work out the bugs!

Hi Stephanie,
I too mentioned some of this same stuff in my response post to Michelle. I am a high school teacher who is also using google classroom with my students. I would be happy to help if you and your daughter still need help. The district is telling teachers to have grace with students. Have you reached out to her teacher to explain the situation and see if she can help remedy the situation and allow her to resubmit?

Chromebooks are hard, they don;t work like regular laptops since they are cloud computers and have no hard drive. I had to take training in Canvas and in person at the district just to be able to barely use them. APS should make a youtube channel or something to help the students and families who are using them now!.

I like how you broke down the elements for cultural inclusivity in course design.

I can relate to your experience with various platforms we use for communication and learning. With eLearning being a novel concept, for some, we now have to learn a new language for each program we use to negotiate varying tools and frameworks.

Regarding your definition of cultural inclusivity, "We can define cultural inclusivity as a guarantee ..." What happens when a participant is not open to sharing their experiences or elements of their identities or personality to strangers in a virtual environment? How can we guarantee that experience is inclusive? 

In my experience teaching, I found that students from Asian, Middle Eastern, and African ethnic backgrounds found it difficult to share personal attributes about themselves as so much of their identities are based on their parents' accomplishments. In other ethnic groups, Latin Americans (Latinx), perceive talking about themselves as bragging which is frown on in their community. 

In my experience within our Zoom meetings, I realized that I hesitate to speak up because I want to be polite to others and give everyone an opportunity to share their views. In real life, I'm a mid-extrovert and enjoy communicating and contributing to conversations. I learned something new about myself that allowed me to reflect on the meaning of cultural inclusivity and how we communicate in-person versus online.

Mark, I completely relate to hesitating to speak up out of politeness! It was only after I taught a few online classes that I realized silence is far worse than overspeaking! There is nothing more demoralizing as a teacher than asking if anyone has questions and hearing nothing! In person, you can see headshakes, read body language and expressions, but even with a great connection, sometimes it's hard to get those clues on a video screen. I think we're all having to reflect on how we communicate online versus in person.

Virtual and eLearning are quite distinct from each and in-person. In virtual facilitation, there must be tools to help learners share and contribute to discussions without causing much distraction. Tools for communication should include speaking, using the chat pod, and participating in polls, or asking questions on the screen that require a response (place a stamp on the right answer, etc.). Also, breakout rooms allow participants to communicate in smaller groups.This is a similar format to the strategies I used in the classroom. eLearning requires its set of tools: asynchronous discussions and a set of rules for engagement and a prefixed manner of contributing and submitting work. 

Not every student is an extrovert or is comfortable speaking publicly. Students/learners should be given an equal opportunity to participate in virtual/eLearning sessions using differentiated tools. In an eLearning enviorment, where there is a diverse representation not only in culture but also in varied experience, people should be given a choice in how and when to communicate given his/her/their preference, when appropriate. 

Would an eLearing course be equitable to an individual who is visually impaired or differently abled? Do you think this is taken into consideration in deisgn?

Mark,

Your second paragraph really resonates with me. It seems a lot of guidelines need to be established to give everyone the space they need to interact at their level of comfort. In the peer mentoring process, I think this is a space for personal growth. Learning to be a holistic healthcare practitioner, in all the modalities I offer, the idea is to "meet your client where they are," so I constantly have to adjust treatments to be more or less verbal, more or less "gossipy" or "precise and anatomical," more "touchy feely" or more "medical," this includes accommodating clients from babies to octogenerians - the health journey these clients entrust me to lead them on is buffered by their knowing they can move at whatever pace they need to in order to let their bodies find portals to self-healing.

Looking at some of the resources in Module 1, I was intrigued to see numerous options for how to read some of the selections -  I would assume these can be considered hands on tools for accommodation.

In spite of these positives, I still can envision the WisCom framework leaving little space for those who cannot assert themselves as well as others so that their input goes under and they give up participating or feel pressured only to participate in order to get a grade/evaluation/or other tangible feedback for which they paid.

Any system with a monetary factor creates a power differential. Maybe WisCom is as altruistic as it may seem not able to truly tap into how e.g. an indigenous wisdom community operaties (taking into consideration the Navajo or Hawaiian models that were discussed).

Thank you for bringing up these points! Eva

Hello, Michelle.  I understand your frustration (case in point, my inability to share my screen during the Zoom meeting the other night).  I feel that I am generally tech savvy, provided I have the time to learn a platform, or that it is at least intuitive.  I agree with your wish list for inclusive course design.  Accessibility is an issue.  The text mentioned that course designers rarely get to choose their LMS platform.  This means when a switch has to be made nearly instantaneously, everyone from the course designer to the facilitator to the student have to adjust quickly, and yes, it is more difficult for some than others.  Also, I think it is awesome that Albuquerque issued ChromeBooks to its students.  However, at my job, some folks had to take non-pandemic work leave when the campus shut down for COVID-19 because they lived in very remote areas with no internet service.  Furthermore, my current city has a 25% poverty rate (pre-COVID), so there are people that live in areas with internet service, but simply cannot afford it.

I totally agree with your third point about problem-solving assignments.  I am interested in learning more about your second point.

Hi Michelle,

I can completely relate to your post of trying to figure out how to navigate these new platforms currently. There are a few that my school is currently wanting us to integrate into our online teaching, but it's taking me a while to try to figure them out. I really like your example of what a culturally inclusive course would encompass. I think your statement about discussions and problem solving assignments not being developed and graded for a one correct answer response. I feel like this is very important. Many times I know teachers look for specific terms and if they are not present in the response then it is marked wrong. I personally try to stray away from doing this because of the fact that I have English Language Learner students who may not be familiar with the terms I am looking for. While APS passed out these chromebooks to our students, I have many students who don't have a parent at home who can help assist them either because they have parents that work or their parent(s) don't understand how to navigate the technology, which puts these students at a disadvantage.

Michelle,
Thank you for your comments.  Your post touched on a issue that I have been thinking about a lot lately.  What about APS students who live with guardians who have little or no experience with technology.  I have met many older people who are raising their grandchildren.  Some of them have never interacted with a personal computer in any meaningful way.  How do we address the "cultural bias" of demanding an online learning platform for those students?  Without an adult who can help them navigate that on line environment, aren't we excluding their culture in a way?  I really don't know, but it seems like it might be an important question.

I agree completely with your concerns. I mean, I use technology constantly on multiple formats (sometimes simultaneously) and I still have to ask my 17-year-old how to do stuff. I can't imagine being handed a Chromebook with no frame of reference! I think you broached perhaps the most important question in regards to online learning--using it as an instructional platform when not everyone has the technological background or access.

It really is an issue and it moves beyond just online learning systems.  Where I work, we run into it.  You have people that have been using the same system of technology for years or even decades.  Then, a decision is made to upgrade.  Now we have two problems: 
1.  How do we alter the entry level training to accommodate the new technology?
2.  How do we design in service training to upgrade current team members to the new technology?
And this whole discussion brings up another piece of the puzzle for me:
3.  Is there a cultural facet for the learners that can cause an issue with that training?  Obviously, not everyone is approaching this from the same place - how do we deal with that and make sure it does not become an obstacle to effective training?
Thanks for keeping the conversation going.  This is really turning into an area that I, honestly, probably had not given enough consideration to in my design work.

Could this be changed into an opportunity for authentic learning where going into a "messy" environment fosters discussion around improvements that are not imposed from the top down but vetted through a community? It's ironic how misleading the work "upgrade" can be in its implications and how it is usually received.

I liked Meagan's comments on the different elements that could be built into eLearning to enhance design. That together with the various comments we've had on language from Melissa, Michelle M., Michelle C., and others, could perhaps be tied in to where you are going with your thoughts.

That's very possible, I think.  Just brainstorming, it occurs to me that you could create a learning community that involved the in service people and the new hires.  That might actually be a really interesting way to approach it.  There would be a lot of interesting cultural perspectives involved .  Drawing from another class I am taking in project management for online learning systems, it might be possible to devise an agile approach to the development of the learning system by creating that type of learning community.  I would speculate that such a system would be very robust, as it took cultural inclusivity into account from the very beginning, instead of trying to work it in as an after thought.  This is a really interesting conversation.  I am glad we are having it.  I see "real world" possibilities here already.
Wow, Pete, yes - when I think about education in the corrections system, which is what I'm currently interested in, the wording you are using really resonates! I'm intrigued.

A while back, I saw a very cool documentary shot in a prison in Indiana where an older inmate was really trying to explain to a brand new inmate the way that he needed to change his mentality in order to survive prison and prevent himself from coming back.  There was an obvious mentor relationship going on there, but it sort of went both ways.  The younger inmate saw the older man as a guide and teacher.  The older inmate almost seemed to view the younger man as a second chance for himself - a way to reverse to prevent the mistakes he had made in the past.
It was pretty cool to observe.

That is so encouraging. After I saw Ava Duvernay's 13th, I started looking for a penpal and have now been corresponding with someone for the last four years. He has gotten his paralegal certificate in the meantime and really is trying to stay positive about things. We have agreed that we have both learned from one another because of the depth and honesty of our exchange. At one point I was able to send books which he read and really liked and which we discussed, including Coehlo's The Alchemist and he has told me that he sees the world differently. Conversely, I wrote a lyrical non-fiction essay based on this, which I've shared with him in an edited form (so it would make it through security) and which I'm looking to get published. We can all learn so much from one another!

Culturally inclusivity in an online environment is creating a space where people can learn from the collective experience of others regardless of ethnic or cultural identity.

This space is co-created by all members of the group who communicate and create rules for engagement. This environment is a centralized location where everyone is a contributor and a learner. People bring their wholes selves and everyone's contributions are appreciated and challenged democratically.

The goal of the group is to gain insight into each other's point of view and experience transformational change via learning and shared experiences. The learned concepts are transferrable to various professional and personal aspects of members' lives. 

Creating an inclusive online community requires intention. The designer and creator of the course must have insight into the topics, discussions, backgrounds, and goals of the learners to fully create an inclusive environment.

Elearning has stereotypes associated with content and delivery. The designer intentionally creates a space that is neutral, devoid of personality, to avoid bias. The goal of the designer is not to offend or identify people or to address a particular culture.

The issue with creating a neutral space for learning is that it is not engaging or it may not appeal to learners.

As Melissa shared in her post certain elements are necessary for creating an intentional inclusive experience for learners.

Ultimately it is impossible to create a natural space for learners. The designer will implement his/her/their own bias in developing learner content based on his/her/their understanding of what is "standard."

In the Goodfellow and Hewling's reading, they mention that elements of the dominant culture linger in the creation of an eLearning environment and are categorized as "standard" in terms of functionality. As we have learned, creating an inclusive experience needs to account for patterns of participation in individualistic and collectivist views as well as high and low context approaches to learning.

In addressing the question on the WisCom Framework I'd like to reference Melissa Herrera's post. 

"Instructional designers can create a culturally inclusive classroom by using the ingredients of the WisCom framework: 

Communication: Through communication, learners can pass on their cultural knowledge to others as opposed to allowing one dominant group to be held responsible for passing on knowledge such as the instructor. It also allows people to understand each other better and help the instructor understand what is needed for learners to be successful and valued within the eLearning community. 
Community: Cultural inclusivity allows for communities to develop where people in an online environment can come together and build a tight-knit group. I noticed how comfortable we are interacting with each other on the discussion boards that when we met for our second Zoom meeting, some of us were interacting like we've known each other for a long time! That is one of the wonderful things about building a community that is culturally inclusive where people respect each other's views and choices.
Technology: We need to be cognizant that not everyone knows how to use a computer, or does not have the bandwidth to do certain things so we need to be patient, teach others, and provide different resources so everyone can meet learning objectives. A culturally inclusive eLearning course does not solely rely on technology; they provide other mediums such as books, handouts, and other resources.
Co-mentoring: We need to work with people of different backgrounds which was something recommended by Tao & Cornell (2003). Co-mentoring is also a great way to provide scaffolding that might be needed for some learners to be successful and learn from each other.
Problem- solving and collaborative inquiry cycle: It is important to remember that not everyone has the same thought process and some cultures focus more on collaborative thinking than individual thinking (Bentley, Tinney, & Chia, 2005). Culturally inclusive classrooms are a mix of individual and collaborative thinking just like we are doing right now. We are sharing our views and synthesizing them into a summary at the end. 
Wisdom: A "wise" instructional designer intentionally creates a culturally inclusive eLearning experience by putting their own culture aside and looking for ways to build a strong learning community
Transformational learning: transformational learning takes place when learning environments allow learners to change their ways of thinking by interacting with learners of a different culture. This is the only way that transformational learning takes place, in my opinion, because sticking to our own beliefs or cultural group will not produce genuine transformational learning because we are not giving up anything. 
Learner support: Cultural inclusivity is all about providing support for the learner. A true culturally inclusive eLearning experience has different support systems for every learner to be successful."
I found the information in her post to be concise and inclusive.


I look forward to reading your contributions and learning from you.

So far, everyone has shared some great ideas revolving Michelle's 3 factors for creating a culturally inclusive eLearning experience. I agree with everyone's statements especially when it comes to having a "tangible platform." This is a challenge that I feel has become a hot topic because of remote learning. Had we not had a pandemic, would this be something most of us would think about with respect to students who are English Learners, disabled, or have no experience with technology? I don't want to get off-track with this, this is just something to think about beyond this discussion. 

I agree with Mark that a challenge instructional designers face is the reliance on building a neutral space that can affect a learner's motivation and interest resulting in no meaningful learning opportunities. That is why we need to consider the different parts of the WisCom model as a key to cultural inclusivity. We need to be intentional in how we communicate, offer learner support and co-mentoring opportunities, use technology, and build a strong community. These will lead to the desired outcome of transformational learning.

Does the CIC offer a platform to explore other devices than the ones you named to serve culture neutrality? Is that even a desired outcome?

I would encourage us to see how group members who have not yet chimed in explore these concepts.

"What does it mean to be culturally inclusive in online course design?"

This seems like an easy question with a simple answer but I find I am stumped to try and define it. I think being culturally inclusive simply put is being apart of something others are not. In regards to the online course design, we can use this simple answer that "we" are all apart of something (this class) that others are not. We have our own community we have formed and know how to operate in. It would be difficult for someone outside of the Course to fully understand the little nuances that we have within it.

Hi Amanda,

So you are approaching this in lines of idiopathic culture? Can we take the concepts of collaboration, reflection, and exploration and elaborate on these relative to the WisCom we are trying to create during this class? Over the course of introductions and sharing one defining influence over the last sessions, can we all come to a consensus of how we are currently collaborating, reflecting, and exploring? Which media are we using? Are we agreeing to disagree on anything and what are the rules involved in that? Will the artifacts we come away with adequately reflect the values of the cyberculture we are building here?

A culturally inclusive online course provides a safe and comfortable learning environment where all participants have the opportunity to succeed. There is framework introduced at the beginning of the course outlining expectations and instructors can ask for feedback from the participants regarding the course setup.

Tying your comments on inclusive online courses back to WisCom.  I think WisCom gives us the core elements to create a framework for our course.  But flexibility to adapt and overlap the elements is key to success. 

An example of overlapping elements:

Imagine a non-native person trying to learn a new skill in a high-context language.  We know that effective communication is essential.  Technology can help to translate the language, but translation alone will not create effective communication.  Context is also needed.  This is where a mentor, who understands the context, would really be helpful to the learning process. Having a sense of purpose/ sense of community draws the learner into the learning process even when there are challenges.

Thanks, All!

Can we bring the idea of "idioculture" into the mix:

An idioculture is a system of knowledge, beliefs, behaviors, and customs shared by members of an interacting group to which members can refer and that serve as the basis of further interaction. Members recognize that they share experiences, and these experiences can be referred to with the expectation they will be understood by other members, thus being used to construct a reality for the participants (Fine, 1987, p.125).

Something that struck me in the various definitions of culture and so diversity was how temporality was addressed in some older ones but then subsumed in more recent definitions; the above definition perhaps encapsulates that in "being used to construct" - I am thinking of examples of ever changing language, habits, norms etc. - just as we are now using pronouns to introduce ourselves in many contexts, in German, e.g. the neutral has been added to job listings and such. Do these kinds of changes factor into creating an idioculture as well?

Dixie, I'm glad you've brought the high-context idea into the discussion. What do we want to look for in an idioculture? How does that reinforce or work with cultural diversity?

Thanks, Eva

The idea of ideoculture here is very intriguing to me Eva! As an early childhood teacher in the past and now a coach and mentor, we often see this play out in the center and in the classrooms as we train our teachers on center philosophy and then then they set the social context and expectations in the classroom utilizing the expected philosophy and pedagogical approaches and adding their own layer of expectations. Even though they may be consistent in application and expectation, we still expect to see ideocultures form amongst the children as small groups find commonalities on other motivations or needs. I would expect that the same would happen within an online learning platform, but this being my first experience being an online learner I am curious to see how this plays our with our entire group as well as small individual groups that will form based on interests and needs. How does this get supported and or guided in this process? I am very interested to hear how you all who are much more familiar with the dynamics of eLearning speak to this. I am assuming that part of this process we are going through is to allow our group learning dynamics too dictate some the pathway for the rest of this course, and it has been very interesting to navigate thus far!

Excellent points you bring up, Lisa; I'm sure your experience will feed into the further discussion as others share about eLearning environments because I do appreciate the point that is cited in "Reconceptualising Culture in Virtual Learning Environments" - 'cultures do not talk to each other; individuals do.' (Scollon & Wong-Scollon, 2001, p 138).
Eva, I agree! While the conceptual understanding is very important, practical and meaningful application must follow or it will nevernhave the impact we all working towards......

This whole thread has been so thought provoking! Regarding idioculture, it seems to be a system that can only be used once those beliefs, knowledge, and customs are established. In eLearning, this might be after a syllabus has been distributed and expectations for the class set (orientation). Is there then a larger idioculture? That being an "American" or "adults who are doing graduate work" idioculture that needs to take into account cultural inclusivity on a broader scale so the more specific idioculture of an online class can operate more effectively?

Or am I just muddying the waters unnecessarily? I feel a bit like I went down a rabbit hole there!

Love that idea! I do think it might take us back into a broader Anthro, Sociology, History place while, going by the definitions of culture offered in the PowerPoint in our module materials, it seems definitions were being looked at chronologically but also contextually landing us in the realm of cyberculture and with idioculture relative to our WisCom at the level we want to stay right now. But your ruminations and fascination reflect what I think everyone is trying to address in some way. Is it a matter of finding the smallest common denominator or do we accept a more messy approach and mixed formats, e.g. with language using macro and micro groupings to solve problems.

This conversation has also made me think about chauvinism a lot and this notion of English as a lingua franca. At what point will English be superseded by Spanish or Chinese? Or x? I bring up this point with regard to comfort levels for participants and natural advantages and disadvantages language skills put participants at. Will there at some point simply be a divide between groups because of language, or could this be turned into something positive, with content being translated into major languages and exchanges being encouraged even if they regularly require translational moments? How would that WisCom look?

As the rest of the world generally speaks more than one language, I think this is something English-only Americans should really think about! I definitely think limited knowledge of languages other than your mother tongue will be an issue as our online educational world grows.

And what about the translation technology that is becoming more and more comprehensive? I know the idea is that you will be able to speak into your phone and it will translate and speak in the language of choice, and what an opportunity to reach people! But what an immense challenge to try to bridge cultural differences. I'm not sure it could be done, but perhaps technology could have a cultural translator as well. 

WisCom in an instance where an automatic translation was occurring might actually require MORE cultural sensitivity from an instructor because you would need to consider all the ways in which your message could be translated--exhausting thought! (And a cultural translator could certainly come in handy for the professor in the short films we are watching!)

Michelle,

I do think it is important to take into account how many people are in fact bi- and trilingual in the US, however they are mostly societally marginalized and not the dominant group to which education caters based on buying power. In fact, I have seen Americans learn foreign languages much more proficiently and be very humble about it compared, e.g. with Germans who think they command umpteen languages when they don't; and I have definitely experienced language chauvinism in France. European countries have myriad ways of engaging and not engaging in language acquisition; perhaps cultivation of local dialects is something that makes many bi-lingual and living in border towns may turn that into trilingual (e.g. on the Swiss border, Germans speak High German, Allemanish and Schwitzerdütsch) but that's based on history, borders, and trade - just like in the US.

That said, in certain parts of the US it is very discouraging how monolingual people are. But then, even UNM last year cut the requirement for how many semesters one has to study a foreign language and on retiring, the Italian professor and thus the program was cut.

I really liked the video Melissa shared. Perhaps the  WisCom framework can create a whole new learning platform for languages.

In my bachelor's program I used several different eLearning course frameworks, such as Moodle, Blackboard and Canvas. All of them had their benefits and drawbacks, personally I liked Blackboard the best. If you could add one feature to a eLearning system, what would it be?

I think eLearning is important because we are a world that is moving to technology only transactions. Many places here locally are only taking debt/credit cards for payment, with sign's stating "due to the coin shortage, please pay with exact change or card." eLearning can lead to difficulty with cultural inclusivity. The definition of "cultural inclusivity," although varies by personal perception, can be reached in a  consensus among peers/classmates. I think the difficulty lies in the application. For example, look at the formal language we use in class discussion. Isn't a discussion board supposed to foster thoughts and response to expand on learning? This omits the personal tone in some individuals way of speaking, we miss the personal or cultural background for understanding. This is just a thought.

Great points! I really liked what you had to say about the verbiage we use in these discussion posts. I think that was a really great observation! 

Alexis

I like your insight into how we are defining eLearning and how we may unintentionally leaving our own cultural assumptions aside to be accepted by our peers as we are collaborating in this discussion. I think this is why people choose not to participate in classroom discussions because they are not familiarized with the academic language and might feel their own connections may not apply which is untrue because making personal connections is more meaningful than utilizing academic language at times.

I so appreciate bringing up this point of language in the context of cultural inclusivity. IN the "Meaning of Culture in Online Education" article, suggestion was made that  "in a cross-cultures synchronous online learning environment, a common language like English can be used for joint activites, but preparation and follow-up activities can be organized locally in their native langue (Van den Breanden & Lambert, 1999)." I wonder how this could translate with regard to different types of "languages" and levels. I recently found a capstone project two students in NY did working with correctional education with a focus on environmentalism awareness during which they chose young adult reading material in order to find a median reading level for the inmates in the class - this approach was assessed positively by both the instructors and the participants, at the same time, the participants proceeded to formulate their contributions at their various language levels.

I wonder whether we can break down these components, such as language and create lists of relevant examples/keywords and perhaps add glossaries for the personal/high context concepts in order to create a map to navigate cultural difference and thus promote diversity?

I think that's a great idea. For language, we can maybe break it into two parts: academic or every day language. For academic language, we can say it is developed through school and subjects (math, reading, social studies, science, and arts) while everyday language comes from the home, community, and Internet (e.g. social media).

This has been yet another thought provoking and engaging discussion. Thank you all for contributing and sharing your perspectives on cultural inclusivity.  I really like the examples and life experiences you share. Also, thanks go to Eva for moderating and helping us direct the discussion. I am very pleased with the discussion so far, and want to thank all of you who have contributed. I would like to ask those who have not yet shared to let us know your perspectives as well.

To add to the previous discussion on defining cultural inclusivity, I feel that inclusion fosters a sense of belonging to a community—feeling appreciated for one’s unique characteristics, perspectives, contributions, and ways of thinking. In inclusive learning environments, participants are encouraged to interact and negotiate meaning with one another. Participants therefore feel comfortable sharing their ideas, their identities, cultures, languages, and ways of seeing the world. We may not know all our learners at the beginning of a course, but if we design online learning environments with cultural inclusivity in mind, by accounting for the expression of different values, beliefs, worldviews, and educational experiences, it will help all learners feel valued, accepted, and respected, contributing to their growth.

I think three important strands of discussion have emerged that warrant further exploration, and some of you have already taken a stab at them.  One of them is the three levels of adapting a course discussed in Chapter 1, translation, localization, and modularization (Marinetti & Dunn, 2012). I argue in favor of localization and cultural contextualization of learning activities rather than globalization, which creates a one size fits all learning design that may not be culturally inclusive. The second strand is defining culture as an idioculture that emerges from the interacting group. How would we design for idiocultures?  The third strand is the role of language. I feel that second language speakers are usually challenged in asynchronous discussions.  Would “translanguaging” or allowing for the full repertoire of a person’s linguistic expression be the answer? How can we address this? I hope to see further discussion on these great ideas you have brought up.

In addition, I would encourage you to take a critical look at the WisCom framework. Some of the questions, I have in mind are:  To what extent does it help us to design with cultural inclusivity in mind.? What type of learner would thrive in a WisCom learning design, and who would feel left out? What is missing in WisCom? How can we improve it?  

Look forward to your thoughts.

Dr. Lani, 

In response to your point about translanguaging, I definitely agree that second language speakers are at a disadvantage in classroom discussions, however I do not have a definitive answer for whether I feel it should be allowed in the classroom. I think to some extent it almost has to be allowed so that students can fully express what they know, but my question is: how will the teacher know what they are expressing if they do not know the other language, and if that is the case is it still worthwhile? I'm curious to hear what my classmate think.

In my family, a lot of us speak a form of Spanglish (Spanish and English mix) when were are together. However, I have never felt comfortable to use it in an academic situation. My reasoning for this is probably fear of feeling ostracized because we are expected to use academic English in school. The difference for me however is that English is my first language, so I don't feel like I need the support of Spanglish or Spanish to express my ideas, but if I was working in a Spanish speaking community I would definitely feel more comfortable using English sometimes or at least some Spanglish. Does anyone have experience with this? Do you think translanguaging works in the classroom?

Stephanie-

I too wonder if there is a "correct" approach to translanguaging in education.

I think medical education takes the reverse approach to this question.  Much of med ed in based in Latin, a language that is likely to be unfamiliar to most.  Students are expected to learn this whole new language in order to correctly communicate in the medical world.  Those who fail to learn the language are generally ostracized.  But with this approach, no one has a true advantage.  We all start out as novices.

In regards to localization vs globalization, I believe you need to identify your audience and your intent.  Some educators are looking to reach a large audience and capitalize on their investment.  There is nothing wrong with this.  But it may guide you in more of a global direction.

Hi All, 

I wanted to share some quick info. regarding translanguaging and how it works in the classroom.

This is great, Melissa!

Would love to get some input from anyone who hasn't had a chance to jump in yet and I'll just repost the last questions Dr. Lani put out here regarding the WisCom framework - I think this video you've shared offers a powerful place from which to explore these questions:

To what extent does it help us to design with cultural inclusivity in mind.? What type of learner would thrive in a WisCom learning design, and who would feel left out? What is missing in WisCom? How can we improve it?

Thanks for the reminder prompt, Eva!

I've actually been thinking a lot about what types of learners would thrive in a WisCom learning design and who might feel left out. At first, I considered that the framework was universal enough that anyone could thrive in it. But then someone (I think it was Mark) mentioned that sometimes he didn't speak up in online classes as much as he might because he was trying to be polite and allow other people to speak. This then got me to thinking about people who might be shy or introverted and feel awkward participating in an online discussion, and then I wondered about people who may have other factors that make participating in a collaborative program untenable. 

For example, I have a child who suffered crippling depression and anxiety (with a host of sub-diagnoses) in high school. We had to get a 504 accessibility plan to enable them to take time off when in a bad state or take longer to turn in an assignment. I'm not certain it would have been possible to enact such a plan if the learning was in an online collaborative environment. Now it might be easy to say, "well then those people shouldn't take an online class" but I think this limits the scope of what WisCom seeks to do which is to provide transformative learning. 

This may not seem like a "cultural" issue, but I'm referencing the article "Reconceptualizing Culture in Virtual Learning" and the idea that "Culture conceptualized in terms of nationality or of ethnicity is limited usefullness in understanding interpersonal interaction because of complexity of influences and determinants within an individual." So essentially, I'm proposing that social and mental health issues fit as a "culture" to be considered in designing a learning platform.

Perhaps what needs to be included in cases like this are options of participating more asynchronously (like this very forum) and the ability to perhaps turn off the camera and only use chat in instances like Zoom meetings. The collaborative side of WisCom may need to consider that some people are not always able to work collaboratively.

Sorry for the extensive read! Oh! and my kiddo has had some tremendous recovery and recently graduated Suma Cum Laude from UNM so everything turned out great in the end!

You made a great point that chat is a great means of communication. This is something we use in our virtual training sessions, and often we get better responses through chat than by allowing them to verbally share.

Hi Melissa and Michelle,

I too agree that chat is a great means of communication. I have found this to be very true while currently teaching my students online. My student's are not comfortable enough to verbally share questions, concerns, connections,etc.  because we are still building relationships with each other, but they are more than willing to type their questions, concerns, connections in the chat box for me to address. The chat function is amazing for my kiddos with Autism who have anxiety with speaking in front of others or who don't like to be seen on the camera. The chat function allows them to still be included and contribute to class discussions without causing them any undue stress.

Michelle,

Wow, what a success story! But wow, what a challenge. I think absolutely there needs to be space in the environment but it sounds like it could be difficult to create the parameters for that. In the two online models that were discussed in Meaning of Culture, I liked how the differentiation came down to rigidity of learning versus flexibility and both having pros and cons. I think it's a standard/human issue that everything has two sides - I just keep seeing the yin/yang image...so much to keep considering - and then just testing and assessing.

Thank you so much for providing this video, Melissa! I was at a loss before viewing it.

Not only may translanguaging give students the confidence to do well, it seems that this method would also help students learn the new second language more quickly as it gives meaning and context (the importance of which someone mentioned in a previous thread) to what they are trying to translate.  I can also see it helping students learn as they must be engaged through all three steps as translation for a non-native speaker of a language requires total focus.  This may also have an advantage to native speakers of course's language, which would be to have them be more engaged with the material as well as they try to explain the nuances and context of their language to the non-native speaker.  Come to think of it, I have had friends where English was not their primary language, and it did force me to look at the material more in depth so I could answer their questions more thoroughly than I would have with another native English speaker.  Finally, it seems as if translanguaging would soften the mentor-mentee boundary.  Wow!  I am super excited!  The pragmatic side of me is now wondering if we should intentionally assign multi-lingual classes to encourage interactive and contextual learning.

Absolutely, Michelle! Translanguaging is a great way for all learners to develop a second language. I am a certified bilingual teacher, and while I haven't had the opportunity to teach in a fully bilingual setting, I have been in classrooms where teachers allow their students to share in their native language and the teacher may respond back in their native language or English. Just this past year, my friend had a student who only spoke Korean and she used her translator to communicate with her and allowed her to share her responses in Korean. I think an eLearning environment we have translators easily available which may be helpful if some of the learners do not speak English.

Great point about the fiscal benefits of a cashless society when it comes to eLearning. I've noticed a lot of retailers such as gas stations and coffee shops using technologies such as Apple Pay and contactless "tap to pay" credit cards. I think as technology becomes more integrated into our lives, a basic understanding of learning through it will be almost required. I wonder how this will affect the older generation?

Hello everyone,

I enjoy reading your posts. It's so nice to get different perspectives from professionals in the field. I'm having a challenging time linking WisCom to the topic. I may have to spend some time re-reading to understand the concepts. I'd appreciate your insight into the topic.

Hey Mark,
Disclaimer:  What I am posting here may be worth exactly what you paid me to post it.
I think it was very helpful to me to break it down into Lani's suggested sub questions.
And, I had to narrow my definition of cultural inclusivity a little.  I narrowed to cultural inclusivity in a learning environment.
That might have been a mental trick I played on myself, but I think it worked.
I thought about how the WisCom model embraces the idea that all learning starts at a social level before it is internalized to the personal level.  I then thought about how WisCom addresses the theory that all learning occurs within the cultural context of the learner.  I did not take culture to mean only the learner's background, but also their culture in the online environment.  For example:  Are they new to technology or a veteran online learner?  Is an online learning environment more or less challenging for them as a student?  Where are they in the zone of proximal development for the online environment,  How does WisCom address these things?

Does that help?  Or did I just confuse you more?  Hopefully, the later to at least some extent.
this was very helpful. Thank you for your insight.

To me, cultural inclusivity is the idea that in a given event, many different cultures are represented. When I was in elementary school (I was homeschooled) a group of homeschoolers had a event at the Air Force base sort of like a world's fair. Each child was assigned a different country and their task was to bring a few items that day that represented their country. Mine was Canada, I don't recall what I had brought for the event, but I do remember sampling different types of world food such as French pastries, Italian pizza and Japanese ice cream. I think this format is a great way of celebrating different cultures in school and allowing each child to express their culture in a positive way. Technology has also helped with the idea of cultural inclusivity, with massive multiplayer games frequently bringing in players from all over the world. I hope this trend continues in the future; as I think it is positive for everyone involved.

I appreciate how you explicitly require representation as a component of your definition of cultural inclusivity. That made me think because we can say we are inclusive and welcoming, open-minded and accepting, but without actually having representation of diversity within a cultural space, there is no test of those claims. In fact, perhaps the opposite, perhaps a lack of representation of diverse cultures might give the lie to a community claiming to be inclusive while not actually taking action to support the ideals of the WisCom Framework for elearning.
