What does it mean to be culturally inclusive in online course design?
I found the idea of breaking this down in several questions to be very helpful when approaching this task.

1.  I define cultural inclusivity in terms of a learning environment or instructional design.  With that approach, my definition would require two presuppositions:

a.  Internalization of knowledge is both a social and individual process (Vygotsky).

b.  Learning takes place within the social and cultural context of the learner.

(Gunawardena/Frechette/Layne 2019).

Therefore, I would define cultural inclusivity as using these presuppositions as the basis to design the learning environment for maximum accessibility.  The environment must recognize that social and cultural contexts can be radically different from student to student.

2.  I think that the theories of learning that support cultural inclusivity are the social cultural perspective and, partially by embracing the later, WisCom.  By recognizing the importance of zones of proximal development, distributed cognition and communities of practice they recognize that learning proceeds from the social level to the individual level and takes place within the social and cultural context of the learner.  Rather than fighting this, WisCom is able to design a culturally inclusive learning environment.
3.  Cultural inclusivity is reflected in online course design by creating a framework which is built upon the foundation of the social cultural perspective and/or WISCOM.  By incorporating those principles into the foundation, a well-designed online course framework is more likely to be culturally inclusive if it does the following:

a. It would recognize that all learning in the online environment will begin at the social level, and then transfer to an individual level.  So, it would create a strong community of practice (a collaborative cognition device) as quickly as possible.

b.  It would recognize that the online environment is likely to contain the most diverse set of social cultural perspectives possible.  For this reason, it would need to be very careful to avoid bias in its construction or operations.
b.  It will embrace that the students may all be in a different zone of proximal development and use that as a strength, not a handicap.  Mentoring plays an enormous role in this in my experience.

c.  It would recognize the transactional distance of different learners and seek to minimize that by reducing structure, simplifying structure that cannot be eliminated and increasing dialogue between members of the community of practice.

4.  The most significant way the WisCom framework helps me think about cultural inclusivity in online design is through its contrast with the community of inquiry (COI) model.  The COI focuses on the individual construction of knowledge.  In an online environment, the COI model would be very difficult to manage or monitor.  WisCom, focuses not on the individual construct, but the group construct.  This seems more in line with the theory of social cultural perspective in learning.  Placing the “wisdom community” at the center of the model is evidence of this. That model, where there are multiple “check ins” by multiple learners and multiple mentors, all of whom may switch roles frequently, sounds much more effective and more accepting of the social cultural model of learning.

I’m sorry if this is a ramble.  I found these chapters of the book very interesting, as I have encountered problems in instructional design which directly relate to some of the theories that are discussed here.  I look forward to learning more about this with all of you.

I agree that cultural inclusivity is all about "maximum accessibility." Your reference to the social constructivist theories discussed in our readings needs to be understood in order to appreciate the WisCom model, especially when it comes to the zone of proximal development (ZDP). As instructional designers, we need to create content that meets the ZDP of our learners and modify as needed. I agree that mentoring and the ability to switch between learner, facilitator, and expert is equally important especially when it comes to building a "wise community." I believe that being inclusive is understanding that as an instructor, we are not "passing on knowledge" instead we are providing opportunities for everyone to share their knowledge and learn from each other.

Pete and Melissa,

Thanks for bringing this to the theory level! I got a book on Constructivism edited by Catherine Twomey Fosnot and there is one chapter on "A Constructivist Perspective from the Emerging Field of Disability Studies," in which among many other things there is a comment regarding the need to reassess how "disability itself is socially constructed through the beliefs and expectations that circulate in the wider out-of-school, as well as in-school, culture." Reference is made to Vygotsky having pointed out in his time that impairment is "socially determined. A difference is just a difference until cultural consensus makes it a problem." I just bring this up in the context of how wide a berth may be necessary to accommodate everyone's ZDP?

Cultural inclusivity is being welcoming and encouraging to people of all cultures to share and have their input valued and respected. Different viewpoints need to be accounted for at the start of the project to ensure equity to all learners. Including capabilities for the software to switch languages, have differentiated content such as audio, visual, games, and written to reach people the most ways possible. The designer can also assemble a list of phonemes, word roots and stories from diverse backgrounds to engage students. The instructional designer can look up common cultural misconceptions ahead of time to foresee possible problems with their curriculum. Some of the theories of learning that emphasize cultural inclusivity include the Cultural-Historical Theory of Vygotsky, Social Constructivism, Group Cognition, and Collaborative Learning. All of these theories emphasize group work and collaborating with a diverse group of people. WisCom promotes cultural inclusivity because it emphasizes Co-Mentoring and the Collaborative Inquiry Cycle. These tasks require people to work directly with different people who can be from anywhere, so it is important to be inclusive from them start.

I really like how you defined cultural inclusivity. You did a great job summing it up. The part that you included about the different viewpoints needing to be accounted for at the start of a project in order to ensure equity to all learners. I think this is a very important part. I am currently using a program called Edgenuity for my chemistry curriculum and one of the reasons I chose to use it is because I have a variety of students with various disabilitlies such as hearing impaired, dyslexic, and sensory processing disorders, as well as have students whose primary language is Spanish, and this program was designed to be used by all, which has been awesome because I am able to meet the needs of all of my students! It is very frustrating as an educator to be teaching and not have necessary supports to help support all of my students, so when a program comes along that accounts for all of these things and ensures equity for all it's awesome.

Based on the definition of culture from Harris & DeSimone as a “set of shared values, beliefs, norms, and artifacts” which guide behavior, being culturally inclusive in online course design can refer to providing multiple means of dissemination of information, interaction with course material and peers, and production and/or assessment. Differentiating an online course in such a manner allows for students of differing cultures to interact with each other, the content, and their professor(s) in authentic and meaningful ways by creating room for the interplay of the multitude of cultural dimensions, including such aspects as high context vs low context, masculine vs. feminine, collectivism vs individualism and so forth. Thus, within the idioculture of a group of cohorts in an online class there is room for individual expression while maintaining functional communication in the online learning environment and thereby fostering increased cross-cultural understanding and a safe cultural space for elearning. When learners have the safety to interact with each other, across cultural barriers, in order to collaborate on complex problems, resulting learning may be transformative leading to the cultivation of online wisdom communities.
